body: TEN years ago, when Karen Brenner first moved to Park Slope, she settled in a rented one-bedroom floor-through on Third Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. In 2001 she moved again. She bought a two-bedroom apartment in a newly built 36-unit condominium called Park Slope Estates on Second Street between Fifth and Fourth Avenues. To outsiders
title: Rezoning, and Redefining, Park Slope

body: THE revised zoning adopted for Park Slope last April affects almost all the blocks from Warren Street south to 15th Street and from Third Avenue to Prospect Park, excluding only a manufacturing zone nearer the Gowanus Canal. It gives Brooklyn its largest contextual zoning district, comparable to others adopted in Manhattan over the years. Its basic
title: How the Zoning Works

author: Susan Dominus is a contributing writer for the magazine.
body: Lucille Roberts b. 1943 In 1969 -- the year man walked on the moon and thousands of hippies descended on Woodstock -- Lucille Roberts, in her mid-20's, staked out her own piece of the future and opened New York's first gym for women. Back then, the handful of gyms in New York were more like high-end spas, places where men lounged in saunas and
title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED; Ladies of the Gym Unite!

body: For the uninitiated, the Atlantic Avenue-Pacific Street subway station in Brooklyn has long been a daunting place, a jungle of confusing signs, dank corridors and complicated twists and turns. A detailed map helps only slightly, revealing a tangle of 10 subway lines running through the terminal, as well as the Long Island Rail Road. Making matters
title: How to Hold Up a Subway Tunnel: Get a Big Hanger; An Unusual Feat of Engineering Makes the Renovation of a Brooklyn Station Possible

body: CHRISTMASTIME in New York: the big tree, department store windows, roasting chestnuts (though they seem to have vanished). For me, the childhood holiday memories include those clichés. But they also include stories that are a little more personal and strange: like the time my family's house got robbed on Christmas Day and, a few years later, the
title: Christmas Carols; Ah, snow-laced memory lanes.The carolers. The Santas. The Christmas night mugging.

title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: When Andrea Fergus, 40, stresses the importance of education to her six children, they can look to her actions as proof of her sincerity. Mrs. Fergus already has two degrees: an associate degree and a bachelor's degree in human services from New York City Technical College. And she is not done yet. She is pursuing a master's degree in psychology at
title: The Neediest Cases; A Family With Many Goals Must First Find a Home

body: During the 22 years Linda Henderson has lived in her Flatbush apartment, she has seen swarms of water bugs, infestations of flies and so many rats she often wondered if she was the interloper in their home. ''They were living on top of the stove,'' said Ms. Henderson, 49. In 1985, after killing the first rat, she took the dead rodent to the
title: The Neediest Cases; Trying to Endure Misfortunes Of Home, Health and Family

body: The developer Bruce Ratner unveiled his plans yesterday to build a Frank Gehry-designed arena for the Nets basketball team near Downtown Brooklyn. He detailed his ambitious $2.5 billion commercial and residential project at a theatrical presentation attended by the mayor, a former basketball star and a best-selling rapper. Whatever political juice
title: A Grand Plan in Brooklyn For the Nets' Arena Complex

body: ONE day, in about four years, James L. Dolan may be stirred from his narcoleptic leadership as Knicks chairman by a hired jostler on retainer at Madison Square Garden. ''Excuse me, sir,'' General Manager Scott Layden may gently say to Dolan. ''Sir, the Nets are at the door.'' Over the last couple of years, Dolan could dismiss the idea of a Nets
title: Sports of The Times; The Knicks May Need To Watch Their Turf

body: The bodies of two men who had been shot to death were discovered on the floor of a Brooklyn parking garage late last night, according to the police. Investigators said the victims were found at 11:20 p.m. in the garage, which is at 3501 Foster Avenue, near Brooklyn Avenue, in East Flatbush. The authorities declined to identity the two men, but said
title: 2 Shot Dead in Brooklyn

body: A man slashed his wife to death with a sword yesterday in the Bronx and then charged at two officers who came to his door, the police said. One of the officers fired a 14-bullet fusillade that wounded the man and the other officer, the police said. The man, Ivor Forbes, 32, was naked, screaming and covered in blood when the two officers arrived at
title: Firing on Murder Suspect, Officer Also Hits Partner

title: 'Portable' Number, Just Out of Reach

The fight ''looks like a dispute between two
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man, 19, Fatally Stabbed

body: EVERYONE knows the traditional New York classics, like E. B. White's ''Here Is New York,'' from 1949, and Joseph Mitchell's ''Bottom of the Harbor'' (1959). But what books published in the past quarter century might join their ranks? When the City section asked readers to nominate ''the new New York classics,'' more than 100 books were suggested.
title: NEW YORK VOICES; Winners' Tales: New York's New Classics

title: Tradition, Tradition, Tradition? Not in American Jewish Music

body: The daily banter at Michou Hair Care goes far beyond hair. It encompasses a new job, an unfaithful boyfriend, a pair of sexy but painful shoes, a coveted day care slot. title: Hair Styling, Plus Cancer Education; Brooklyn Health Project Goes Where the Women Are

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Ditmas Park and Ditmas Park West; Spirited Enclaves With Grand Homes

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Bullet Hits Man Lying In Bed

author: Franz Lidz is the author of ''Ghosty Men: The Strange but True Story of the Collyer Brothers, New York's Greatest Hoarders,'' being published this month by Bloomsbury.
body: MY father never had much use for fairy tales. The fifth of five brothers raised in a one-bedroom tenement on the Lower East Side, he preferred real-life grotesqueries. And so at bedtime, I would listen raptly to his urban horror stories, tales that filled the dark with chimera, bogeymen, golems. The most macabre was the tale of the Collyer
title: The Paper Chase

body: New York can be a notoriously difficult place to create works of art. E.B. White, whose 1949 book ''Here Is New York'' is one of the most eloquent tributes to the city, famously made a special trip by train from his home in North Brooklin, Me., to research the work, and after a few sweaty days at the Algonquin Hotel, went right back home to write.
title: URBAN TACTICS; The City as Muse

title: Student, 19, Is Found Shot to Death on a Brooklyn Sidewalk

body: TWO colonial villages, Bedford and Stuyvesant, long ago merged to form one Brooklyn neighborhood, but in some ways, the place that took both villages' names remains two communities, represented by $500,000 brownstones to the south and public housing towers in the north. It is a neighborhood with 200 block associations and more than a dozen
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bedford-Stuyvesant; Brownstones by the Tree-Lined Block

Despite our antsy, adolescent irreverence, there was something about those books that commanded immediate attention,
title: So It Is Written: Books Are Memory

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Wanted In Carjacking And Rape

body: A 35-year-old man and a 15-year-old boy were wounded early yesterday in a shooting in Flatbush, the police said. Officers arrived at the scene of the shooting, at Flatbush Avenue and Beverly Road, at 5:25 a.m. The man had suffered a gunshot wound to the leg. The boy had also suffered a gunshot wound, though the police did not have details last
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Injured In Shooting

body: Vertical Fire Hydrant Q. During the blackout this month, I went for a run in Central Park and noticed that the fountain in the middle of the Reservoir was still running. Is it battery-operated? A. It is pleasant to contemplate a fountain that runs, Rube Goldberg style, on thousands of submerged double-A's. But in reality, the Reservoir fountain is
title: F.Y.I.

body: A union of health care workers rushed to complete its work this week as Labor Day approached -- not by painting picket signs, but rather by preening plumes and stringing sequins. For the last four months, members of 1199/S.E.I.U. climbed 19 steep steps each day to a rented space above Golden Krust Caribbean Bakery and Grill in East Flatbush,
title: Union Puts Caribbean-Style Fun Into Labor Day

body: EVEN if you think you know New York -- and no one truly does, not in its entirety, vast and varied -- an occasional chance to see a part of the city fresh through someone else's eyes is too good to pass up. So the answer was an eager yes when the offer came to join a bunch of newly minted Brooklyn College professors on a bus tour the other morning
title: NYC; Brooklyn, A Rich Stew Tasted Anew

body: Bob Bender wound the propeller just so. He released the model plane, which sailed and looped and soared almost up to the ceiling of Hangar B at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. Its several-minute jaunt -- time appeared to be suspended -- was powered by an unwinding rubber band. For a little over three years now, Mr. Bender, 78, has been bringing
title: Where Rubber Meets the Sky; A Veteran Winds Up the 'Motor' and Lets It Fly

body: AFTER 9/11, we became the Sally Field of cities. ''You like me!'' Ms. Field gushed after winning the 1984 Academy Award for best actress. That was New York after the terrorist attack: barely able to believe the affection showered on it by the rest of the country. Now, after the great blackout of 2003, the city seems to have morphed into the urban
title: NYC; Tell Mars: New Yorkers Come in Peace

body: IT all began on a whim, on a Sunday afternoon drive in early spring two years ago. Barbara Brown-Allen and her husband, Michael Allen, were living happily in a modest house in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. They owned a four-family building in Brownsville, too -- an investment property, nothing fancy, just a safe place to grow a nest egg. Life was sweet
title: Habitats/Crown Heights, Brooklyn; Rescuing a Near-Mansion With Rats in Its Parlors

body: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly released crime statistics yesterday that showed looting during last week's blackout began quickly, but remained light relative to the 1977 blackout, with about five dozen incidents concentrated largely in central Brooklyn. ''The first window broke on Flatbush Avenue about 10 minutes after the blackout'' began,
title: Central Parts Of Brooklyn Saw the Worst Of Looting

body: Over the long weekend, the tales grew in the telling. Miles heroically crossed on foot. Eons trapped in the subway. A night on the sidewalk. Flights of stairs like Everest. So when many New Yorkers finally saw their co-workers yesterday for the first time since the blackout, it was time to brag -- and complain. Anthony Leone, 45, an MCI engineer,
title: THE BLACKOUT: NEW YORKERS; War Stories at the Water Cooler

author: Jonathan Mahler is writing a book about New York and baseball in the 70's.
body: By the time darkness descended on New York on Thursday evening, I was eating a pizza with a friend on my stoop in Park Slope, Brooklyn. We wanted to hear the end of the Yankee game, so we got into my car and started driving. Pretty soon we'd picked up five middle-aged Russian women who had been walking from Midtown Manhattan to Brighton Beach.
title: The New York That's Visible in the Dark

body: With the lights back on yesterday in New York City, several shopkeepers said they had returned to work to find their stores broken into and their merchandise gone. The police took reports of everything from precious stones to boxes of diapers snatched while the lights and alarms were out. A handful of reports of looting, which the police said
title: THE BLACKOUT: THE NEIGHBORHOODS; For Owners of Stores Hit by Looters, Low Crime Rate During Crisis Is No Comfort

body: SOME of the residents of Avenue I sat on front stoops Thursday night, chatting in the glow of flashlights about the blackout that had enveloped their corner of Brooklyn. But even in this precious moment of conviviality, Janelle Barabash could not help herself; she had to say it. You know, she said. The parrots didn't do this. Every neighborhood has
title: About New York; Bright Birds, Dark City? Not This Time

body: You can keep a refrigerator closed for only so long. As powerless hours ticked by yesterday and thermometers crept upward, this cruel fact gnawed away at purveyors of foodstuffs all over the city. ''I have not opened my boxes yet,'' Annette Criscitelli, an owner of the Da Nico restaurant in Little Italy, said at lunchtime, referring to her walk-in
title: THE BLACKOUT: RESTAURANTS; Many Businesses Swallow Hard, Then Throw Out Food

body: New York City was a crime scene waiting to happen, the imposed darkness offering a nearly perfect opportunity for those inclined to help themselves to whatever their neighborhoods had to offer: computers, jewelry, groceries, cellular phones. No cash, just carry. But while about 250 people were arrested in what the police described as
title: THE BLACKOUT: CRIME; This Time, Fewer Arrests As the City Stayed Dark

body: IT is summer, when some of us will look for any flimsy excuse to be outside. There are people who can sit on a stoop, point their chins toward the sun and call it a day. I admire them. But there are also those of us, guilt-ridden, who need to feel we are going somewhere or doing something. The city, accommodating of most relatively harmless
title: ART REVIEW; A Seasonal Migration of Cultural Scope

body: The strains within YankeeNets, once heralded as a model for sports conglomerates, are so deep and bitter that the holding company is close to breaking apart, according to people involved with the company. If YankeeNets dissolves -- considered a near certainty by people involved in the company's recent dealings -- it could ultimately result in the
title: SPORTS BUSINESS; YankeeNets Unravels, And Teams May Move

body: The hot-pink ribbon drew, at best, passive interest yesterday from those gathered at the Grand Army Plaza subway stop in Brooklyn. One man breezily glided his hand over the nylon strip, tied tight across four columns by the track for Manhattan-bound trains. Another man parked his bicycle by it. Others sat staring at everything but it. None noticed
title: Never Mind the Closing Doors. Just Watch the Posters.

body: Before Park Slope became a variant of TriBeCa -- before the sake bars and $250 throw pillows arrived -- Alison Houtte was this Brooklyn neighborhood's most glamorous asset. Ms. Houtte is one-quarter inch short of standing six feet tall and looks like Ali MacGraw without the vague air of melancholy. During the era in which the neighborhood's dress
title: MY BROOKLYN; Clothes With Tales to Tell and Lives to Enliven

body: This is the season of long shots in federal court in Brooklyn. More precisely, 495 long shots by prisoners begging for another day in court with stories that read like movie scripts. Jack B. Weinstein, an 81-year-old judge who is known by lawyers for crisp decisiveness, is in the midst of a crash project to clear up what some judges admit was an
title: Unbelievable Stories (Just Ask the Judge); A Last Hearing for 495 Lost Causes, Each One 'a Movie of the Week'

body: A 15-year-old girl and her baby sister who vanished after a Saturday evening trip to the Kings Plaza shopping center were found safe yesterday afternoon, the police and family members said. The girls, Tarsha Mason and her 22-month-old sister, Kendria Hamilton, were found at the home of one of Ms. Mason's friends in Canarsie after the police
title: Two Girls Missing Since Saturday Are Found Safe

body: ON a muggy July day nine years ago, Jim Kennelly and two fellow firefighters plunged five or six times each to the bottom of Coney Island Creek, their eyes clenched against the filthy water, to rescue five unconscious people tangled inside a wheels-up car 10 feet down on the creek bed. ''When I broke the surface to go under water, it was eerie,
title: A Firefighter's Other Passion: Changing The Skyline

body: New York City is getting two more ''early-college high schools'' this fall, part of a national wave of such schools designed to help minority and low-income students complete high school and get a jump on college before they graduate. Both schools will be small, with no more than 500 students, and will emphasize science. They are being created in
title: 'Early College' Gains Ground In Education

author: Steve Kurutz is a staff writer for Details magazine.
body: THE Belt Parkway, which stretches for 36 miles from Owls Head Park in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to Long Island, is a road as bold and monolithic as New York City itself. The highway, which was built by Robert Moses, is lined with concrete barriers and colossal traffic jams on weekends. Driving the Belt is like skirting along the very heart of urbanism.
title: In the Still of the Night

body: The driver of a commuter van was fatally shot by one of his passengers as the van traveled south through a busy commercial section of Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday. The shooting sent people fleeing in panic and led to a series of crashes. The police said the shooting occurred yesterday afternoon in front of 2184 Flatbush Avenue in Flatlands
title: Brooklyn Dollar Van Driver Is Shot to Death by Passenger

title: How Many Schools Have Ties To Both Burr and Barbra?

body: NO matter where you live, Southern-fried chicken is the ultimate picnic food. It is best eaten with your hands when you are propped up on an elbow, stretched out on a blanket. With summer bearing down, I set out to find the city's best takeout birds, Southern-fried and bundled up in large quantities to take to the park, the beach or the rooftop.
title: A Southern-Fried Picnic, to Go

body: The police have released a photo of a man who is wanted for questioning in the killing of Romona Moore, a 21-year-old Hunter College psychology major whose naked body was found behind a boarded-up building just blocks from her home in East Flatbush on May 10. Ms. Moore disappeared on the way from a friend's house to a Burger King restaurant on her
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Wanted For Questioning

body: The Wyckoff House will never blend in. The 17th-century farmhouse, built by a Dutchman who arrived in the New World as an indentured servant, is surrounded by garages and a junkyard. But the curators of the Wyckoff House, the city's oldest house, at Clarendon Road and Ralph Avenue, have embarked on a project that they think will make it more
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST FLATBUSH; Where Crops Grew Long Ago, A Plan to Plant Again

body: A body found wrapped in a blanket behind a boarded-up house on Saturday was identified by the police yesterday as that of Ramona Moore, a 21-year-old Hunter College student who lived at home with her parents in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, until she disappeared in April. The cause of death was blunt trauma to the head, a spokeswoman for the city
title: Body Discovered in Brooklyn Is Identified as Hunter Student

body: The ailanthus is the tree that grows in Brooklyn, but it's the cherry tree that lights up the borough these spring days. The Brooklyn Botanic Garden is a showplace for more than 200 ornamental flowering cherry trees in 45 varieties -- now in different stages of bloom -- with luminescent petals ranging from the palest baby-girl pink to the shade of
title: A Beauty as Fleeting as Life

body: The day after a deliberately set fire killed four people in a third-floor apartment in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, residents and city officials said that the building that burned was overcrowded. At least seven families were living in the three-story building, which was supposed to have only one apartment on each floor, and the third floor was
title: Overcrowding Cited in Fire That Killed 4 In Brooklyn

body: A deliberately set fire fueled by a liquid accelerant tore through a Brooklyn apartment house early yesterday, leaving four people dead, officials said. The three-alarm arson began on the first floor of the three-story building at 2586 Bedford Avenue in East Flatbush. But the victims -- three men and a young woman -- were all in a third-floor
title: Fire Kills 4 In Brooklyn; Arson Seen

body: A Brooklyn man facing a capital murder charge was accused yesterday of another, earlier murder that is also eligible for the death penalty. The man, Emile Dixon, 32, was arraigned yesterday in federal court in Brooklyn on charges that he killed a man, Alphonso Gooden, in a turf war between drug dealers in Flatbush in 1992. He could face the death
title: With New Charge, a 2nd Capital Murder Case Is Possible for Man

body: SHAKIRA STEWART, a sophomore at Hofstra University, does not always have $4.25 to spare, the cost of train fare between the Hofstra campus, in Hempstead, and Brooklyn, where her mother and grandmother live. So Ms. Stewart, who is paying her own way through college, borrows it from a friend. Now she will have to borrow a bit more. Ten days ago, the
title: Commuters Bracing For Fare Increases

body: His colleagues in the New York Police Department believe that the last words Detective James V. Nemorin heard were ''Give it up!'' And that is what he did. He gave up his life last week while trying to remove a few more illegal guns from the unpredictable streets of his adopted country. Risk is an accepted part of what it means to be a police
title: White-Glove Farewell to Officer Who Embraced Life of Risk

body: An off-duty police officer had three times the legal level of alcohol in his blood when his car collided with another car carrying a middle-aged couple in Brooklyn last week, in a crash that killed all three people, the police said yesterday. At first, investigators did not find any evidence that the officer, Michael McGibbon, 28, had been drinking
title: Officer in Fatal Crash Was Drunk, Test Finds

body: Al Farooq Mosque in Brooklyn, a six-story converted factory trimmed in orange and gold, has been many things to many people during its life: a mystery, a noisy neighbor, a source of suspicion, and, for thousands of Muslims who live or work along Atlantic Avenue, the main street of Arab Brooklyn, a place of worship. Last week, the mosque became, not
title: Brooklyn Mosque Becomes Terror Icon, but Federal Case Is Unclear

title: FAMILY FARE

body: An off-duty police officer and a husband and wife on their way to work at a bakery were killed early yesterday when their cars collided at a Brooklyn intersection, the police said. title: Married Couple and Officer Are Killed When Cars Collide

body: Events NEW YORK CITY POLICE MUSEUM. Scavenger hunt and make-believe line-up today at 10 a.m.; composite drawing workshop tomorrow at noon; appearance by the crime-prevention mascot McGruff the Dog tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the museum, 100 Old Slip, between Water and South Streets, Lower Manhattan. Suggested admission, $5; $2 for children 6 to 18.
title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. ISAAC ALDERSON, Blarney Star, 43 Murray Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 732-2873. A triple all-Ireland champion -- on uilleann pipes, tin whistle and flute -- plays traditional
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

body: EVENTS THUNDERBIRD AMERICAN INDIAN DANCERS' DANCE CONCERT AND POWWOW, Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village. Final weekend featuring participants from the Northwest, the Southwest, the Plains States and the Arctic. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday (Kids' Day) at 2 and 5 p.m. Tickets, $10; children under 12
title: SPARE TIMES

body: ANSIS-Murray. On February 12, 2003. Beloved husband of Miriam. Loving father of Karen. Services today, 1PM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J, Brooklyn)
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ANSIS, MURRAY

body: ON the far wall of the captain's office at the 67th Precinct headquarters is an oversize map of the West Indian neighborhood in East Flatbush. This map tracks the year's shootings and killings. Until last week, it had been pierced only with four yellow pushpins. Yellow signifies a shooting. Shortly after 7 a.m. last Tuesday, though, Capt. Ralph
title: Two Precincts, Two Worlds; East Flatbush: Stolen Cars, Murder in a Maroon Jeep

body: A young woman from Brooklyn was fatally shot and four other people were wounded early yesterday when at least one man opened fire at a party in a crowded East Flatbush catering hall, the authorities said. Detectives yesterday afternoon were still interviewing witnesses to the 2 a.m. shooting at the Charlena Chateau, a licensed cabaret at 3820
title: Woman, 17, Is Killed and 4 Are Shot at Party in Brooklyn

body: EISNER - Edward. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Loving father of Marian Eisner and Joan Freiman and father-in-law of Rich Kessler and Andrew Freiman. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra. Devoted brother of Jack Eisner and Florence Matthews. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services today 10:30 AM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial
title: Paid Notice: Deaths EISNER, EDWARD

body: Until a hand-held anemometer -- a wind gauge -- becomes widely available to New Yorkers, pinpointing the coldest and windiest point in the city will be impossible. But there is a contender in Brooklyn: when pedestrians approach 1 Hanson Place, home to the Williamsburgh Savings Bank, they wrap their coats more tightly, secure their hats, and hunch
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; Outside This Famed Bank, Everyone Knows It's Windy

body: Like the city they serve, MetroCard machines are multilingual. They all display English and Spanish, as well as two other languages chosen from several already programmed in: Chinese, Russian, Korean, Italian, French and Japanese. But City Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. noticed that yet another language of the city, Greek, was not available at the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ASTORIA; MetroCard Machines, Already Fluent In 8 Languages, Add to Their Roster

body: Over the course of his long and distinguished career as a homicide detective in the Garda Siochana, Chief Superintendent Peter McGarr has beaten the drums for Irish history, Irish legend and Irish literature, while doing his bit to curb the uncivil excesses of Irish politics, Irish religion and Irish criminal enterprise. So it seems only fitting
title: CRIME

body: TIRED of special effects? How about special causes? That's what unbuilt architectural designs represent. Models and drawings need not be poor substitutes for completed buildings. They possess their own intrinsic interest. They are links in the chain of causality that produces, sustains and transforms major cities over time. And if a design is
title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; A See-Through Library of Shifting Shapes and Colors

body: Last month, just before winter break, parents and teachers at the Montessori Day School learned that starting this summer, the school would be dropped as a program of the Y.W.C.A. of Brooklyn, which has housed and supported it for 17 years. The news, they said, came out of nowhere. ''We had no advance warning,'' said Joyce Evans, co-president of
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Montessori School With a Deficit May Be a Victim of a Y 's Deficit

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. Opera ''THE BARTERED BRIDE.'' Every season the Bronx Opera, a scrappy company that has been presenting opera in the Bronx for 35 years, takes one production to the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: A homeless man has been arrested in the rape of a 19-year-old woman in Prospect Park, the police said yesterday. The man, Rodney Florvil, 43, was charged with first-degree rape after he was taken into custody on Saturday near Empire Boulevard and Flatbush Avenue. Investigators said the woman, whose identity was not disclosed, reported being
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Rape At Park

author: Adam Fifield collaborated with Wayne Barrett on ''Rudy! An Investigative Biography of Rudolph Giuliani.''
body: ON a slate-gray afternoon at a Midtown construction site, seven men in hard hats and yellow rain gear stepped into a steel cage suspended over a dark hole nearly 60 stories deep. The last man on board latched the door shut, and the cage sank away from daylight and toward a sonorous, mechanical roar far below. The men inserted earplugs and then
title: The Underground Men

body: Feats of Feet What happens when a white South African ballet dancer begins teaching ballet to black children from the poorest townships, as in the 2002 short film ''Guguletu,'' above, directed by Kristin Pichaske? How does a master choreographer collaborate with a master composer? Questions like these will be addressed when the the 31st year of the
title: Footlights
